data.title: Geography in German: 129 Words to Spark Your Wanderlust
data.meta_description: Weâll teach you some of the most exciting geography landform terms, from rivers, beaches, and oceans to hills and mountains in German.
data.text:
Germany, Austria and Switzerland all have scenic landscapes to offer, including countless breathtaking lakes and impressive mountain chains - from the beachy coastline of the North Sea to the snowy mountain tops of the Alps.

Thereâs so much beauty in nature, which makes it a great topic to talk about when youâre learning German. It includes fascinating landscape features including different bodies of water and landforms that will never let you run out of things to talk about in German.

Learning about geography in German can also help you:

Plan your next camping or hiking trip to a German-speaking country

Find the most impressive natural landmarks when traveling

Find your way when the person youâre asking is referring to landmarks as reference points

Strike a conversation about the landscape with a German-speaker

Write a pretty nature poem in German

How do you say âlandformsâ and âwater bodiesâ in German

Weâll teach you some of the most important geography terms, from rivers and oceans to hills and mountains in German.

âLandformsâ in German are âOberflÃ¤chenformenâ [ËoËbÉËflÉÃ§nÌ©ËfÉÊmÉn]. If you break down the word, itâs a lot less intimidating:

âOberflÃ¤cheâ means âsurface (literally: upper area) and âFormenâ means âshapesâ.

The German word for âWater bodiesâ is even simpler: GewÃ¤sser.

The most common landforms and bodies of water in German

When youâre learning the most commonly used landform terms in German, some of the categories may overlap, but weâll do our best to keep it as logical as possible, starting with coastal and oceanic landforms.

Coastal and oceanic landforms in German

Austria and Switzerland are landlocked countries but a long stretch of Northern Germany borders on the Baltic Sea and the North Sea. You may not typically think of Germany as a country with many beaches but the reality looks very different!

You can find a long shoreline and countless beautiful beachy islands in Germany like FÃ¶hr, Sylt and RÃ¼gen.

Erosion landforms in German

Erosion is the process that wears out earthen materials through wind and water. While this process often seems destructive, itâs brought us some of the most beautiful landscape features such as canyons, caves and fjords.

Fluvial landforms

Fluvial landforms are shaped by running water. They dominate many of our landscapes, even those that seem arid today.

English German IPARiverDer Fluss[flÊs]River islandDie Flussinsel[flÊsËÉªnzlÌ©]ShoalDie Sandbank[ËzantËbaÅk]SpringDie Quelle[ËkvÉlÉ]AidDer Werder[ËvÉÊdÉ]BenchDie Schorre; die Brandungsplattform[ÊÉÉÌ¯É; ËbÊandÊÅsËplatËfÉÊm]EskerDer Os[oËs]FloodplainDie Flussaue[flÊsËaÊÌ¯É]LeveeDer Deich[daÉªÌ¯Ã§]MarshDer Sumpf[zÊmpÍ¡f]SwampDer Bruch[bÊÊx]MeanderDer MÃ¤ander[mÉËandÉ]StreamDer Strom[ÊtÊoËm]RiffleDie Stromschnelle[ËÊtÊoËmËÊnÉlÉ]WaterfallDer Wasserfall[ËvasÉËfal]

Impact landforms in German

When a large object hits the earth, this of course impacts its surface. 15 Million years ago for example, an asteroid hit the earth where Bavaria is today and the result is a huge crate called the âNÃ¶rdlinger Riesâ that is still very visible today.

English GermanIPACraterDer Krater[ËkÊaËtÉ]Meteor craterDer Meteorkrater[meteËoËÉÌ¯ËkÊaËtÉ]Impact craterDer Einschlagkrater[ËaÉªÌ¯nËÊlaËkËkÊaËtÉ]Complex craterKomplexer Krater [kÉmËplÉksÉ ËkÊaËtÉ]Cratered landscapeDie Kraterlandschaft[ËkÊaËtÉËlantÊaft]Crater lakeDer Kratersee[ËkÊaËtÉËzeË]

Mountains and glacial landforms in German

Austria, Switzerland and the South of Germany are highly mountainous as Europeâs highest and most extensive mountain range, the Alps, stretches through all three countries. This gives these countries their distinctive look that brings to mind charming little mountain towns, surrounded by the beautiful snowy Alps.

English GermanIPAHillDer HÃ¼gel[ËhyËÉ¡lÌ©]MountainDer Berg[bÉÊk]RidgeDer Kamm[kam]GlacierDer Gletscher[ËÉ¡lÉtÍ¡ÊÉ]CrevasseDie Gletscherspalte[ËÉ¡lÉtÍ¡ÊÉËÊpaltÉ]Glacier caveDie HÃ¶hle[ËhÃ¸ËlÉ]Mountain rangeDas Gebirge[É¡ÉËbÉªÊÉ¡É]Mountain chainDie Gebirgskette[É¡ÉËbÉªÊksËkÉtÉ]Mountain passDer Gebirgspass[É¡ÉËbÉªÊksËpas]ArÃªteDer Gebirgsgrat[É¡ÉËbÉªÊÉ¡sÉ¡ÊaËt]CirqueDas Kar[kaËÉÌ¯]ColDie Scharte[ËÊaÊtÉ]CoveDie Einbuchtung[ËaÉªÌ¯nËbÊxtÊÅ]Dirt coneDer Sandkegel[zantËkeËÉ¡lÌ©]ValleyDas Tal[taËl]Side valleyDas Seitental[ËzaÉªÌ¯tnÌ©taËl]HighlandDas Hochland[ËhoËxËlant]SummitDer Gipfel[ËÉ¡ÉªpÍ¡flÌ©]InselbergDer Inselberg[ËÉªnzlÌ©bÉÊk]Outwash plainDer Sander[ËzandÉ]

Volcanic landforms in German

Did you know there were more than 30 volcanoes in Germany? Donât worry about them when youâre visiting though. The last one erupted around 11,000 years ago!

English GermanIPAGeyserDer Geysir[ËÉ¡aÉªÌ¯ziËÉÌ¯]LavaDie Lava[ËlaËva]MagmaDas Magma[ËmaÉ¡ma]VolcanoDer Vulkan[vÊlËkaËn]Shield volcanoDer Schildvulkan[ËÊÉªltvÊlËkaËn]SupervolcanoDer Supervulkan[ËzuËpÉvÊlËkaËn]CalderaDie Caldera[kalËdeËÊa]GuyotDie Tiefseekuppe[ËtiËfËzeËËkÊpÉ]SeamountDer Tiefseeberg[ËtiËfËzeËËbÉÊk]Lava domeDer Lavadom[ËlaËvadoËm]Lava fieldDas Lavafeld[ËlaËvaËfÉlt]Lava lakeDer Lavasee[ËlaËvaËzeË]MaarDas Maar[maËÉÌ¯]Volcanic crater lakeVulkanischer Kratersee[vÊlËkaËnÉªÊÉ ËkÊaËtÉËzeË]

Bodies of water in German

These terms are especially important because they describe most of the wonders we have on our little blue planet as an impressive 71% of the Earth's surface is water-covered.

English GermanIPAWater massDie Wassermasse[ËvasÉËmasÉ]OceanDer Ozean[ËotseaËn]SeaDas Meer[meËÉÌ¯]LakeDer See[zeË]RiverDer Fluss[flÊs]CreekDer Bach[bax]PondDer Teich[taÉªÌ¯Ã§]Sea armDer Meeresarm[ËmeËÊÉsËÊaÊm]ReservoirDer Stausee[ËÊtaÊÌ¯ËzeË]BayDie Bucht[bÊxt]BayouDer Bayou[baËjuË]CanalDer Kanal[kaËnaËl]River deltaDas Flussdelta[flÊsËdÉlta]Hot springDie Thermalquelle[tÉÊËmaËlËkvÉlÉ]LagoonDie Lagune[ËlaËÉ¡uËnÉ]LochDer Loch[lÉx]MangroveDie Mangrove[mÉÌ.É¡ÊÉv]Mediterranean seaDas Mittelmeer[ËmÉªtlÌ©meËÉÌ¯]Mill pondDer MÃ¼hlenteich[ËmyËlÉntaÉªÌ¯Ã§]PuddleDie PfÃ¼tze[ËpfÊtÍ¡sÉ]WetlandDas Feuchtgebiet[ËfÉÉªÌ¯Ã§tÉ¡ÉËbiËt]BogDas Moor[moËÉÌ¯]PortDer Hafen[ËhaËfn]

Phrases or idioms that contain landforms in German

If someone mentions a âsilence in the forestâ in German (Schweigen im Walde), theyâre referring to an awkward silence.

To save you from any of those awkward silences in the forest, weâll make sure you never run out of things to say in German. Thatâs why we always teach you plenty of idioms that you can use in a conversation.

German Literal translationMeaningIPABerge versetzen kÃ¶nnenTo be able to move mountainsTo do something so difficult itâs almost impossible[ËbÉÊÉ¡É fÉÉÌ¯ËzÉtÍ¡snÌ© ËkÅnÉn]Wie ein Strich in der LandschaftLike a line in the landscapeExtremely skinny[viË aÉªÌ¯n ÊtÊÉªÃ§ Éªn deËÉÌ¯ ËlantÊaft]Wie Sand am MeerLike sand by the seaA dime a dozen[viË Ëzant am ËmeËÉÌ¯]Nah am Wasser gebaut seinTo be built close to the waterTo cry easily[naË am ËvasÉ É¡ÉËbaÊÌ¯t zaÉªÌ¯n]Ins kalte Wasser springenTo jump into the cold waterTo jump in at the deep end[ Éªns kaltÉ ËvasÉ ËÊpÊÉªÅÉn]Den Wald vor lauter BÃ¤umen nicht sehenTo not see the forest from so many treesCan't see the forest for the trees[deËn valt foËÉÌ¯ ËlaÊÌ¯tÉ ËbÉÉªÌ¯mÉn nÉªÃ§t ËzeËÉn]Es herrscht Schweigen im WaldeThereâs silence in the forestThereâs an awkward silence[És hÉÊÊt ËÊvaÉªÌ¯É¡nÌ© Éªm valt]

Scenic highlights of German-speaking countries

If you ever get to travel to a German-speaking country, you can look forward to some impressive natural landmarks.

Southern Germany, Austria and Switzerland are filled with forested hills and some larger mountains like the Alps. In the North, Germany flattens out all the way to the North Sea and the Baltic Sea, which offer lovely sandy beaches.

These are some of the scenic highlights that these countries have to offer:

The Black Forest

Despite its name, the Black Forest is a lush green woodland area with an abundance of wildlife and wild plants. What makes it so special is how pure and wild it is: Some areas have been purposefully left untouched by humans for more than 100 years.

This makes it the ideal habitat for a number of rare and endangered birds like the fastest bird in the world, the peregrine falcon, and Europeâs smallest owl, the pygmy owl.

Vulkanland

The Styrian Volcanic Land in Austria gets its name from the remains of volcanoes that are millions of years old and still visible as hills in the region. Today, the area is a popular wine-growing area, so make sure you also try a local German wine when youâre there!

OstseebÃ¤der

Germany has a number of so-called âOstseebÃ¤derâ (Baltic Sea Baths) like the Ostseebad TravemÃ¼nde or Sellin on the island of RÃ¼gen. These little gems by the Baltic Sea are places with beautiful sandy beaches and a distinct beach culture.

The Alps

Switzerland, Liechtenstein, Austria and Germany are all Alpine countries, so donât forget your hiking boots when youâre visiting! If you love nature and especially the mountains, you wonât wanna miss out on this stunning mountain chain!

Lakes Constance

Lake Constance, the so-called âBodenseeâ is where Germany, Austria and Switzerland meet. As Germanyâs largest lake and the third biggest lake in Europe, itâs a popular tourist destination, with deep blue water and a scenic view of the Alps in the background.

Lake Geneva

Lake Geneva is on the French-Swiss border and offers fancy spa resorts as well as beautiful hiking trails through flowery patches of nature.

Lake Hallstatt

This lake is beautifully situated in Austriaâs Salzkammergut region and surrounded by a number of little villages that could be straight from a storybook.

Plan your dream vacation

When you go to bed tonight, youâre probably dreaming of scenic landscapes and counting sheep-shaped clouds above the Alps before you fall asleep. Whether youâve decided to visit the sandy beaches of the Ostsee or the sleepy towns in the Swiss Alps, your dream vacation is waiting - and the best way to prepare for a trip to a German-speaking country is with a German class of course.

Thereâs just no better way to experience a country than by chatting to the locals and getting all the insider tips that tourists miss out on. Youâll be fluent in no time because remember, with enough motivation and endurance, you can move mountains!
